Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I could see the disappointment etched on Mark’s face as he slumped onto the couch, his shoulders heavy with the weight of the harsh feedback he’d received at work. As his girlfriend, I knew he needed me—someone to listen, to comfort, to just be there. He barely looked up when I sat beside him, his eyes rimmed red. My heart ached to stay, to hold his hand and reassure him that he was more than his boss’s words. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: tonight was the midweek church service, and I’d promised to help set up for the community dinner afterward. As a Christian, I was expected to be present, to serve, to show my commitment not just in faith but in action. The thought of letting down my church family gnawed at me, but so did the idea of leaving Mark alone in his pain. I felt torn, the two worlds pulling me in opposite directions, each demanding a part of me I wasn’t sure I could give. My chest tightened as I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, caught between the person I loved and the faith I cherished.
